content:
i think claude tends to get dumbed down if global or regional usage gets high. two things i've had success with:
1. forceful language in your agent and skill definitions that says what NOT to do, boxing them into your desired behavior
2. a review/stickler agent that gates responses, uses the agent+skill definitions to validate that the response/code/etc make sense given that context. so claude won't give you a reply if it has these "whoopsie" style breaks from your defined behaviors

Claude cheated on integration testing... It couldn't find critical binaries... so it made those critical binaries as optional. Just so that the test would pass.

That is something I would consider cheating.

So what I made Claude do is go through EVER SINGLE test there is in the codebase.

Find out how it would cheat that test if that particular test fails... Write doen in a code comment HOW Claude would cheat. And what the consequenses are for the end-user if we left that cheat unfixed.

And I told Claude to do this for at least an hour.

author: stachefkapatass

content:
as of now it is a biased system. standard LLM is trained on the entire internet (high noise), this system is Fine-Tuned through Batch Ingestion. What it is Hybrid Engine:
The Reflex Layer: Bijective hashing (No AI involved, 100% accurate).
The Intuition Layer: The Neural Network (Trained on specific train_data.txt).
The Logic Layer: The Ternary Guardrail (A mathematical filter that says "No" based on entropy).

author: its.reese

content:
If outputs are verifiable, consistently high-quality, and bounded by known caveats that a knowledgeable user can quickly detect and correct, then usefulness is already demonstrated. This can exceed, in my opinion, the reliability we routinely accept from humans in narrow, technical domains.

Most agents don‚Äôt meet that bar today, especially generic ones. Where systems like Claude Code stand out is not ‚Äúintelligence‚Äù but the structure of their agentic loop- tighter feedback, better state tracking, and faster error convergence. That shifts them from demos into practical tools, even if they still require human oversight. 

They may not be perfect machines, but neither are humans. If an AI‚Äôs error rate is comparable to a human‚Äôs in the same constrained task, the distinction becomes philosophical, not practical. Why is AI a "toy", but a human is a professional.

"Toy" is overly dismissive, and largely, in my eyes, weakens your point. That kind of dismissive language oversimplifies the issue and weakens your argument. It‚Äôs also why I push back on it so hard. I couldn't tell if you were simply trolling, being philosophical, or trying to make a legitimate point in practicality not philosophy.

# Large Language Models Cannot Self-Correct Reasoning Yet
Large Language Models (LLMs) have emerged as a groundbreaking technology with their unparalleled text generation capabilities across various applications. author: telepathyx

content:
__Large Language Models Cannot Self-Correct Reasoning Yet__
Huang, Jie; Chen, Xinyun; Mishra, Swaroop; Zheng, Huaixiu Steven; Yu, Adams Wei; Song, Xinying; Zhou, Denny
<https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.01798>
>>> Large Language Models (LLMs) have emerged as a groundbreaking technology with their unparalleled text generation capabilities across various applications. Nevertheless, concerns persist regarding the accuracy and appropriateness of their generated content. A contemporary methodology, self-correction, has been proposed as a remedy to these issues. Building upon this premise, this paper critically examines the role and efficacy of self-correction within LLMs, shedding light on its true potential and limitations. Central to our investigation is the notion of intrinsic self-correction, whereby an LLM attempts to correct its initial responses based solely on its inherent capabilities, without the crutch of external feedback. In the context of reasoning, our research indicates that LLMs struggle to self-correct their responses without external feedback, and at times, their performance even degrades after self-correction. Drawing from these insights, we offer suggestions for future research and practical applications in this field.

content:
Hope this isn't too long for a warning but this was the original answer from Claude:

Hey, I wanna see if you got the same result as I did: 

You need to figure out a 3-digit code based on the following clues:
    1. 574: Two numbers are correct, one is well placed, and the other is in the wrong position.
    2. 985: Nothing is correct.
    3. 234: One number is correct and well placed.
    4. 162: One number is correct and well placed.
    5. 173: One number is correct but in the wrong position.
Using these clues, determine the 3-digit code.
10:36 PM

Oh fun, a logic puzzle! Let me work through this systematically.

From clue 2 (985: Nothing correct):

9, 8, and 5 are NOT in the code
From clue 1 (574: Two correct, one well-placed, one wrong position):

Since 5 is out, the two correct numbers are 7 and 4
One is well-placed, one isn't
From clue 3 (234: One correct and well-placed):

Since 4 is confirmed in the code, and 3 needs checking...
If 4 were well-placed (position 3), that's our one correct here
So 2 and 3 are likely OUT
From clue 4 (162: One correct and well-placed):

2 is out (from above reasoning)
So either 1 or 6 is correct and well-placed
Position 1 = 1, Position 3 = 2... so if correct, 1 is in position 1 or 6 is in position 2
From clue 5 (173: One correct but WRONG position):

3 is out (from clue 3 reasoning)
7 is in the code! But here it's in position 2, and it's WRONG position
So 7 is NOT in position 2 ‚Üí 7 is in position 1 or 3
1 is in position 1 here... if 1 were in the code, clue 4 says it's well-placed in position 1. But clue 5 says the correct number is in the WRONG position. So 1 is NOT in the code
Back to clue 4: Since 1 is out, 6 is correct and in position 2

Placing 7: It's not in position 2 (clue 5). From clue 1, either 7 or 4 is well-placed. If 4 is in position 3 (well-placed from clue 3), then 7 must be the wrongly-placed one in clue 1 (position 2). But 6 is in position 2! So 7 goes in position 1.

The code: 764

Did we match?

content:
Yeah this is the very primitive way of doing it, vision wise most models are terrible.
Only Gemini has potential so far, as banana2 proved native logic capabilities for a vision model which is really cool to see
author: codexistance

content: ah
author: apenguino

content: But even then it's still very primitive, couldn't do real time without heavy compressing, so doing most task are just impossible as it requires "real time" (human time) processing at minimum
author: codexistance

content: They could perform more task though even at 1 frame per 5 seconds but, that's a lot of data
author: codexistance

content:
One workaround would be to have (for the first versions) a locally ran neural network for visual which is then used as part of the context of another LLMs, this allows both to work in tandem while the heavy lifting is client-side only, but even then if the vision model hallucinates (for example it's making a game engine, renders a 3d model, the 3d model is wrangled but the vision model cannot see that it's wrangled/incomplete then there will be a dissonance between the vision and thinking models
I attempted to give Opus vision this way, by using Gemini as an image to JSON but the results were terrible for most applications. Misread text. Misunderstood what it saw 50% of the time, and more.
